{"step_by_step_thinking": "Infective endocarditis is characterized by several clinical features. Roth spots, which are retinal hemorrhages, and Osler's nodes, which are subcutaneous nodules found on hands and feet, are both mentioned in the documents as features of infective endocarditis. Positive blood culture is also a key diagnostic feature of infective endocarditis as it helps identify the causative organism. However, Aschoff nodules are not mentioned in the context of infective endocarditis in any of the documents. In fact, Aschoff nodules are typically associated with rheumatic fever, not infective endocarditis.", "answer_choice": "C"}
